@ismailhaggag1859  A differential equation is one that relates a function with its rate of change.

@ismailhaggag1859  Since 2y/x in this case is the same as 2x, the reason why 2y/x is used is that now we have a Y corresponds to dy so that we could do the separation of variables and thereby a differential equation allowing us to end with the function of eclipse.

Parth bhayya at 33:15 profesor jerrison says it works for a=0 but a=e^c and an exponential function can't be zero.So was he saying about general quadratic function instead of the double slope geometric problem when he was mentioning a=0 case or am I missing something?
Is it because of the perpendicular curves?
I am also not used to the concept, so I searched on google. you can check the link below.  https://www.intmath.com/plane-analytic-geometry/1d-perpendicular-lines.php

Let's say the angle that one line makes with x-axis is alpha. So if another line is perpendicular to it, the angle that it makes with x-axis will be alpha+90 (W.L.O.G.). Then the corresponding slopes are: tan(alpha) and tan(alpha+90). The latter is the same as -cot(alpha). Finally, the product of the slopes of two lines is: tan(alpha)*(-cot(alpha))=-1.
@yb2209  great link! The sentence "Perpendicular lines have the property that the product of their slopes is −1." is really the key bit there
